title: Global Central Banks Ramp Up Inflation Fight
abstract: Central banks in the U.S., Europe, Canada and parts of Asia are lifting interest rates rapidly as they try to wrestle breakneck inflation under control.
byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Eshe Nelson

multimedia.caption: The central bank in the Philippines surprised investors with a three-quarter point move last week.

title: Netflix, Still Reeling, Bets Big on ‘The Gray Man’
abstract: The streaming service hopes its latest release can be the start of a blockbuster franchise that attracts much-needed subscribers.

multimedia.caption: Ryan Gosling stars in “The Gray Man,” which Netflix will start streaming on Friday.
Ryan Gosling stars in “The Gray Man,” which Netflix will start streaming on Friday.

title: The World Economy Is Imperiled by a Force Hiding in Plain Sight
abstract: Well more than two years into the worst pandemic in a century, the accompanying economic shock continues to assault global fortunes.

multimedia.copyright: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

title: The Dollar Is Extremely Strong, Pushing Down the World
abstract: The value of the U.S. dollar is the strongest it has been in a generation, devaluing other currencies and unsettling the global economic outlook.
byline: By Karl Russell, Joe Rennison and Jason Karaian

title: A Warren Buffett Protégée Strikes Out on Her Own
abstract: Tracy Britt Cool spent a decade working closely with the renowned investor. She is now applying those lessons to her own firm.

multimedia.caption: “I’m not building a Berkshire 2.0,” Tracy Britt Cool said of Kanbrick.

title: The Magic of Your First Work Friends
abstract: Early-career connections can be life-defining. For young people entering the work force today, the connections over Zoom are shaky.

multimedia.caption: Lisa Degliantoni, left, and Ginny Cahill at Sussex Publishers in New York in 1998.

title: Stock Market Drop Accelerated as Recession Seemed More Likely
abstract: Further losses may be on the way, even after a 20 percent drop in the first half of the year, as Wall Street continues to price in the Fed’s aggressive interest rate policy.

title: Energy Was the Only Bright Spot in the Stock Market’s Gloom
abstract: But Russia’s war in Ukraine creates uncertainty about where energy funds will go in the second half of the year.

title: The Week in Business: Twitter Hits Back
abstract: Inflation in June was high. The euro tumbled to parity with the U.S. dollar. And central banks around the world are raising interest rates.

title: 4 Killed in Indiana Mall Shooting, Officials Say
abstract: The attack unfolded at the Greenwood Park Mall in Greenwood, Ind., on Sunday before an armed man fatally shot the assailant, city officials said.
byline: By Vimal Patel and Melina Delkic

multimedia.caption: Two additional people were hospitalized in the shooting, city officials said. The authorities did not indicate a motive for the shooting.
multimedia.copyright: Lee Klafczynski for The New York Times

title: After New Abortion Laws, Some Patients Have Trouble Obtaining Miscarriage Treatment
abstract: Surgical procedures and medication for miscarriages are identical to those for abortion, and some patients report delayed or denied miscarriage care because doctors and pharmacists fear running afoul of abortion bans.

multimedia.caption: Before Texas’s restrictive abortion law took effect, Amanda received a standard surgical procedure for a miscarriage. After the law, when she had another miscarriage, she said the same hospital declined to perform surgery and sent her home with instructions to return only if her bleeding was so excessive that it filled a diaper more than once an hour.
multimedia.copyright: Nancy Newberry for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Before Texas’s restrictive abortion law took effect, Amanda received a standard surgical procedure for a miscarriage. After the law, when she had another miscarriage, she said the same hospital declined to perform surgery and sent her home with instructions to return only if her bleeding was so excessive that it filled a diaper more than once an hour.
multimedia.copyright: Nancy Newberry for The New York Times

title: Jewelry and Gems Worth Millions Stolen From Brink’s Truck in California
abstract: The value of the missing merchandise, which was headed last week to an International Gem and Jewelry Show event, was unclear. One conservative figure put the value at up to $10 million.

multimedia.caption: Jewelry and gems among those stolen last week from a Brink’s armored car in California.
Jewelry and gems among those stolen last week from a Brink’s armored car in California.
Jewelry and gems among those stolen last week from a Brink’s armored car in California.

title: Passengers Sigh as Heathrow Caps Numbers to Head Off ‘Airmageddon’
abstract: After two years of pandemic-enforced staycations, demand for travel has come roaring back in Europe, and airports are finding it impossible to keep up.

multimedia.caption: Travelers on Wednesday at London’s Heathrow Airport. The airport has capped the number of departing passengers until September.
Travelers on Wednesday at London’s Heathrow Airport. The airport has capped the number of departing passengers until September.
Travelers on Wednesday at London’s Heathrow Airport. The airport has capped the number of departing passengers until September.

title: Another Pain Point in a Summer of Travel Woes: Getting a Passport
abstract: If you’re urgently in need of a new or updated passport, brace yourself: Options have narrowed — and it’s likely going to cost you.

title: Nikole Hannah-Jones and University Settle Hiring Dispute
abstract: Ms. Hannah-Jones, who won a Pulitzer Prize for the 1619 Project, had said she was considering legal action against the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

abstract: The United States has ordered nearly seven million doses in total, but most of them will not arrive for months.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Elon Musk Claps Back at Twitter’s Lawsuit Over $44 Billion Deal
abstract: Mr. Musk formally responded to Twitter’s attempt to force him to buy the company, arguing that there was no reason to hurry the case.
byline: By Lauren Hirsch, Kate Conger and Matthew Goldstein

multimedia.caption: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, filed a response to Twitter on Friday after the company sued him to go through with an acquisition.
Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, filed a response to Twitter on Friday after the company sued him to go through with an acquisition.

title: Texas and its power system prepare for more high temperatures.
abstract: Readings of 100 or more are forecast throughout the coming week in much of the state.

multimedia.caption: A transmission tower near the CenterPoint Energy power plant in Houston.
A transmission tower near the CenterPoint Energy power plant in Houston.

title: Biden Administration Retreats on Threat to Withhold Arizona Relief Funds
abstract: The Treasury disbursed $2.1 billion in pandemic aid after warning it could be withheld because the state had used aid money to undercut school mask mandates.

multimedia.caption: Arizona’s Republican-controlled Legislature banned school mask mandates in 2021, in defiance of the Biden administration’s public health guidelines. Some school districts imposed them anyway.

title: Fresh Data Give Fed Wiggle Room on Rates at July Meeting
abstract: Inflation expectations eased, even as retail sales looked strong. That gives central bankers room to stick to their rate plan — or speed it up.

multimedia.caption: Retail sales in June were unexpectedly strong, suggesting that demand is chugging along even as the Fed works to restrain it.
Retail sales in June were unexpectedly strong, suggesting that demand is chugging along even as the Fed works to restrain it.
Retail sales in June were unexpectedly strong, suggesting that demand is chugging along even as the Fed works to restrain it.

title: Frontier Airlines’ bid for Spirit faces an advisory firm’s opposition.
abstract: Institutional Shareholder Services said a rival offer from JetBlue was more valuable, despite concerns about regulatory hurdles.

multimedia.caption: A shareholder vote on a sale of Spirit Airlines to Frontier Airlines has been postponed several times.
A shareholder vote on a sale of Spirit Airlines to Frontier Airlines has been postponed several times.
A shareholder vote on a sale of Spirit Airlines to Frontier Airlines has been postponed several times.

title: Big Banks Send Mixed Signals on Economic Outlook
abstract: In their latest financial reports, Wells Fargo showed signs of trouble but Citigroup revealed results that were better than expected.
byline: By Stephen Gandel and Emily Flitter

title: Voters See a Bad Economy, Even if They’re Doing OK
abstract: A New York Times/Siena poll shows remarkable pessimism despite the labor market’s resilience. That could be costly for the Democrats, and the economy.
byline: By Ben Casselman and Lydia DePillis

title: Retail sales rise more than expected, keeping pressure on the Fed.
abstract: Central bank officials are watching closely for signs that the economy is running hot, stoking inflation, and strong spending in June could push them closer to a bigger interest rate increase.
byline: By Isabella Simonetti and Jeanna Smialek

title: Average Car Payments Hit a Record High. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: The average monthly payment is now about $700. But shoppers have options, including looking for less expensive smaller vehicles.

title: China’s Shuddering Economic Engine
abstract: Widespread lockdowns and mass quarantines in China has had far-reaching consequences for the global economy.
byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross

multimedia.caption: Dark clouds ahead.
Dark clouds ahead.
Dark clouds ahead.

title: Germany Hopes to Outrace a Russian Gas Cutoff and Bone Cold Winter
abstract: Europe’s largest economy and key energy hub still depends on gas supplies now ensnared in conflict. Here’s how Germany is preparing and what is at stake.
byline: By Patricia Cohen and Melissa Eddy

multimedia.caption: A furnace casting stainless steel at the Schmees factory in Pirna, Germany.

title: How to Get In on the Electric Vehicle Boom
abstract: One way is through investing in companies that make batteries for those vehicles and those that mine and process the minerals in the batteries.

title: It’s Been a Poor Year So Far for Municipal Bonds
abstract: Still, investors may have cause for optimism since yields on the bonds are rising and many state and local governments are financially flush.

title: Would You Pay $40 a Month to Have Strangers Watch You Work?
abstract: People still working remotely are turning to virtual co-working spaces for accountability through a Zoom screen.

title: China’s Economy Hits a Slump as Covid Policy Takes a Toll
abstract: High unemployment, a housing market in crisis and sluggish consumer spending during lockdowns are putting pressure on Beijing in a year when officials are focused on projecting stability.

multimedia.caption: A textile factory in Nantong, China. China’s economy in the second quarter expanded 0.4 percent from a year earlier.

title: Facts Were Sparse on an Abortion Case. But That Didn’t Stop the Attacks.
abstract: The story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio became the focus of a heated political debate that played out in the news media.

multimedia.caption: The facts of the case became clearer on Wednesday, when The Columbus Dispatch reported that a man in Ohio had been arraigned in the rape of a 10-year-old girl.

abstract: An automated fraud filter improperly froze thousands of customers’ accounts, regulators said.

title: A watchdog report absolves financial transactions made by two top Fed officials.
abstract: The Fed’s chair and vice chair did not violate any rules, the report found. Still, some found the description of the vice chair’s trades unsatisfying.

multimedia.caption: Jerome H. Powell, chair of the Federal Reserve, asked for an inspector general investigation into financial trades by Fed officials at a moment when the central bank was actively propping up markets.
